content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

Given a DataFrame `df` with column `dt` representing DateTimes. Write a function `add_yearmonth` that creates a new column `ym` by extracting year and month from `dt` and concatenating them together as an integer in format: “yyyymm”.

```juliafunction add_yearmonth(df::DataFrame)
 newcolumnname = "ym"
 df[:ym] = map(x -> string(year(x)) * string(month(x, "01-01")) *, df.dt)
 df.ym .= map(x -> parse(Int, x) *, df.ym)
 end
```

This function accepts a DataFrame `df` as an argument and creates a new column `ym` with the desired format. It uses the `map` function to extract year and month from each DateTime in the `dt` column and concatenates them together using string manipulation. Finally, it converts the resulting strings to integers using the `parse` function and assigns the new column to the DataFrame using the `.` notation.
